Find out if you qualify for Council Tax Support and how we work out how much help you can get.

Basic eligibility rules

To qualify for Council Tax Support, you must meet all of these basic rules:

  • You are liable to pay council tax (as an owner or tenant)
  • You live in the property as your main home
  • The property is in Gloucester
  • You are on a low income or receive certain benefits

Good news: You can still apply if you are working, own your home, or are self-employed. Council Tax Support is not just for people who are unemployed.

Income and savings limits

If you are working age (under State Pension age)

If you are under State Pension age (currently 66), these limits apply:

Savings limit: ¬£16,000

You cannot get Council Tax Support if your savings and capital are over ¬£16,000. This includes:

  • Money in bank accounts and savings accounts
  • Premium bonds and investments
  • Property you own (but not your main home)
  • Value of vehicles (except one car for personal use)

Savings between ¬£6,000 and ¬£16,000

If you have savings between ¬£6,000 and ¬£16,000, we treat every ¬£250 (or part of ¬£250) over ¬£6,000 as income of ¬£1 per week.

Example: If you have ¬£8,000 in savings, we treat this as ¬£8 per week income (¬£2,000 √∑ ¬£250 = 8).

If you are pension age (State Pension age or over)

If you or your partner have reached State Pension age (currently 66), different rules apply:

Savings limit: ¬£10,000

We treat savings between ¬£10,000 and any amount as income at ¬£1 per week for every ¬£500 (or part of ¬£500) over ¬£10,000.

Important: There is no upper savings limit if you are pension age. You can still get Council Tax Support even if you have savings over ¬£16,000.

How we work out your support

We look at several factors when we work out if you qualify and how much support you can get.

Your income

We count most types of income, including:

Earnings from work

  • Wages and salary (after tax and National Insurance)
  • Self-employed profits
  • Bonuses and overtime

Note: We ignore some of your earnings to encourage working. If you are working age, we ignore ¬£25 per week (or more in some cases).

Benefits and pensions

  • State Pension
  • Private or workplace pensions
  • Universal Credit
  • Employment and Support Allowance (ESA)
  • Jobseeker's Allowance (JSA)
  • Pension Credit

Note: Some benefits are ignored, including Disability Living Allowance, Personal Independence Payment, and Child Benefit.

Other income

  • Income from boarders or lodgers
  • Maintenance payments
  • Rental income from property you own
  • Income from savings and investments

Your household

Who lives with you affects how much support you can get. We consider:

  • Your partner: If you live with a partner (married, civil partner, or living together as a couple), we count their income and savings too
  • Children: Dependent children increase the amount of income you can have and still get support
  • Non-dependants: Adults who live with you (like grown-up children or relatives) may reduce your support, as we expect them to contribute to household costs
  • Carers: If someone looks after you or your partner, this may increase your support

Non-dependant deductions: If you have adult children or other adults living with you who are working, we reduce your support by a set amount each week. This is because we expect them to contribute to household costs. You must tell us if anyone moves in or out.

Your circumstances

Certain circumstances can increase your support. You may get more help if:

  • You or your partner are disabled
  • You or your partner are a carer
  • You have dependent children
  • You are a single parent
  • You or your partner are severely sight impaired (blind)
  • You have reached State Pension age

Maximum support - passported benefits

You may get maximum Council Tax Support (up to 100% of your bill paid) if you receive:

  • Income Support
  • Income-based Jobseeker's Allowance
  • Income-related Employment and Support Allowance
  • Pension Credit (Guarantee Credit)

If you receive Universal Credit, the amount of support depends on your income and circumstances.

Who cannot get Council Tax Support

You cannot get Council Tax Support if:

  • You have savings over ¬£16,000 (if you are working age)
  • You are a full-time student (unless you are disabled, have children, or are a single parent)
  • You are subject to immigration control and have no recourse to public funds
  • You live in a care home and the council pays for your care
  • Your income is high enough that your calculated support is less than 50p per week

Students: Full-time students normally cannot get Council Tax Support. However, you may qualify if you are a single parent, disabled, or have a disabled partner. See our students page for more information about student exemptions.

Apply for Council Tax Support

If you think you might qualify, apply online. We will check your eligibility and let you know how much support you can get.

Apply now

Quick eligibility check

Not sure if you qualify? The best way to find out is to apply. We will check your circumstances and tell you if you are eligible.

Most people who get Universal Credit, Pension Credit, or are on a low income will qualify for some help.
